You do not have to be good.
You do not have to walk on your knees
for a hundred miles through the desert repenting.
You only have to let the soft animal of your body
love what it loves.

"Wild Geese" opens with what might be the most generous five lines in modern poetry. Not a command, not a lesson — a release. "You do not have to be good." We expect poems to tell us to be better. Oliver starts by letting us off the hook entirely.

"You only have to let the soft animal of your body / love what it loves." This is not hedonism. It's something closer to trust. The soft animal of your body knows things. It knows what it's drawn to, what makes it come alive, what feels like home. And so much of life is spent overriding those signals in favor of what we think we should want.

The poem continues from here into a wider landscape — geese flying overhead, the world offering itself to your imagination — but these opening lines are where most people get stopped in their tracks. They carry the weight of permission, and permission, it turns out, is what many of us most desperately need.

This morning, consider: what does the soft animal of your body love? Not what should you love. Not what would be impressive to love. Just — what do you actually love?

I am living just as the century ends.

A great rain is coming. The fields are already wet.
I watch the valley from a window. The grasses
change their color as the year advances.

I am not young. And yet I feel young.
What is time? The leaves are blowing.
Life unrolls like an endless bolt of cloth.

Merwin writes without punctuation, as if even the pauses between thoughts are part of the same unbroken fabric. There are no full stops here — just as there are none in experience, not really. One moment flows into the next, the rain into the field, the year into the year.

What catches us is the plainness of his noticing. Grasses changing color. A window. A valley. He is not describing anything extraordinary, and that is precisely the point. The extraordinary is always already here, folded into the unremarkable texture of an afternoon. We just keep forgetting to look.

"I am not young. And yet I feel young." This is not denial or nostalgia — it is a different kind of attention. The body ages. The calendar turns. But something in us remains startled by existence, still watching the leaves blow as if for the first time. Merwin gives us permission to hold both truths at once: the weight of time passing and the lightness of being present within it.

Life unrolls like an endless bolt of cloth. We are somewhere in the middle of it, unable to see the whole pattern. And maybe that is enough — to feel the texture of this one stretch, right here, under our hands.

If the doors of perception were cleansed every thing would appear to man as it is, Infinite. For man has closed himself up, till he sees all things thro' narrow chinks of his cavern.
The Marriage of Heaven and Hell

Blake wrote these lines in the throes of revolution—French, American, industrial—when the old orders were cracking open. Yet his revolution was interior: a war against the dulling of the senses, against the way habit turns the miraculous into furniture.

What strikes me most is that word "cleansed." Not sharpened, not improved, not upgraded. Cleansed—as if our ordinary perception is already sufficient, merely obscured. We don't need new eyes; we need to wash the film from the ones we have. The infinite isn't hiding somewhere exotic. It's here, in the grain of the wooden table, in the steam rising from a cup, in the particular way light falls through a window this morning and will never fall quite the same way again.

The "narrow chinks" feel uncomfortably familiar. How much of any given day do we actually see? We navigate by category and assumption, by mental shorthand that gets us efficiently from task to task while the world streams past unwitnessed. This isn't a failing so much as a necessity—we'd be overwhelmed otherwise. But Blake is pointing to something we lose in the trade: the strangeness of existence itself, the raw fact that anything exists at all rather than nothing.

There's no technique offered here, no five-step program for cleansing perception. Perhaps the awareness alone is the beginning—noticing the cavern, feeling the narrowness of the chinks. Sometimes a single moment of genuine attention, a pause in the rushing, lets a sliver of the infinite leak through. The coffee tastes like something. The face across the table becomes, briefly, unfathomable. The world, for one breath, is new.

The question is not what you look at, but what you see.

Thoreau jotted this line in his journal on August 5, 1851, likely after one of his daily walks through the woods and fields around Concord. It's the kind of sentence that seems obvious at first—of course seeing and looking are different—until you catch yourself staring at a tree you've passed a thousand times and realize you've never actually *seen* it. The bark's texture, the particular angle of its limbs, the way light pools in its crown.

We live in an age of relentless looking. Screens, feeds, windows, mirrors—our eyes are busy from waking until sleep. But Thoreau's distinction cuts through the noise. Looking is mechanical, passive, a function of having eyes pointed in a direction. Seeing requires something more: a quality of presence, a willingness to let the world in rather than simply scanning it for information or utility. A child sees. A distracted commuter looks.

What's quietly radical here is the implication that reality isn't fixed—it shifts depending on the attention we bring to it. Two people can stand before the same pond, the same face, the same page, and inhabit entirely different worlds. One finds nothing; the other finds everything. The difference isn't in the object but in the observer. This isn't mysticism; it's simple phenomenology. We participate in creating what we experience.

Perhaps the question worth sitting with today is: what have I been looking at that I haven't yet seen? A familiar room, a person I think I know, my own reflection. The world is patient. It waits for us to arrive.

Once upon a time, I, Chuang Chou, dreamt that I was a butterfly, fluttering hither and thither, to all intents and purposes a butterfly. I was conscious only of my happiness as a butterfly, unaware that I was Chou. Soon I awaked, and there I was, veritably myself again. Now I do not know whether I was then a man dreaming I was a butterfly, or whether I am now a butterfly, dreaming I am a man.

There's a sly humor in Chuang Tzu's declaration that he returned to being "veritably" himself, followed immediately by the elegant collapse of that certainty. We all know this sensation—the groggy conviction upon waking that we have settled back into our proper skin, only to carry with us the lingering emotional residue of whatever world we just left. The dream felt real; waking feels real; both cannot be true, yet both felt undeniable in their moment. The word "veritably" stands guard like a sentry who has already fallen asleep on duty, insisting on a security that the story immediately dissolves.

What strikes me most is not the philosophical puzzle but the butterfly's complete absorption in its own existence. Chuang Tzu was "conscious only of my happiness," unaware of any Chou who might be dreaming. There is a profound relief in this total immersion, a suspension of the self-consciousness that plagues our waking hours. The butterfly does not question its reality; it simply flutters, drinks, and is. We spend so much effort constructing and defending our sense of "veritably myself"—our stories, our boundaries, our certainties about who we are and what we are not—when perhaps the happier state is forgetting the dreamer entirely.

Yet the story ends not with anxiety but with a shrug, a philosophical laugh that echoes across millennia. To not know whether one is man or butterfly is not a crisis but a liberation from the rigid categories we impose on fluid experience. Perhaps the point is not to solve the riddle but to recognize that we are always, in some sense, dreaming and being dreamed, changing and being changed. The boundary between selves is more permeable than we comfortably admit, and reality less fragile than our desperate need to name it.

I dwell in Possibility –
A fairer House than Prose –
More numerous of Windows –
Superior – for Doors –

Of Chambers as the Cedars –
Impregnable of eye –
And for an everlasting Roof
The Gambrels of the Sky –

Of Visitors – the fairest –
For Occupation – This –
The spreading wide my narrow Hands
To gather Paradise –

There is a particular pressure in modern life to live in prose. We are asked to be practical, realistic, to dwell in the declarative sentences of what is already known. Bills must be paid, schedules kept, expectations met. But Emily Dickinson suggests we might choose a different address entirely—a house built not of brick and constraint, but of windows and sky.

Notice how she constructs this dwelling. It has more windows than prose, suggesting a structure designed for light rather than security. The doors are superior, implying that leaving is as important as entering, that this house is meant for passage rather than permanence. The chambers smell of cedar, impregnable to the intrusive eye, offering privacy for the strange work of becoming. And the roof? Not slate or tile, but the gambrels of the sky itself—an architecture that opens endlessly upward rather than closing protectively overhead.

What strikes me most is the final image: spreading narrow hands to gather Paradise. We expect grand gestures for such a task, arms thrown wide to capture the infinite. But Dickinson gives us narrow hands, human hands, limited in their reach. The gathering is not about grasping the whole sky, but about the posture of openness, the willingness to receive what falls into our small circumference. 

We wake each morning to the same choice. We can inhabit the house that has already been built for us—the prose of obligation and precedent—or we can dwell in possibility, where the floors are uneven and the rooms rearrange themselves, but where the light is different, and the doors, thank God, swing both ways.

We cannot know his legendary head
with eyes like ripening fruit. And yet his torso
is still suffused with brilliance from inside,
like a lamp, in which his gaze, now turned to low,

gleams in all its power. Otherwise
the curved breast could not dazzle you so, nor could
a smile run through the placid hips and thighs
to that dark center where procreation flared.

Otherwise this stone would seem defaced
beneath the translucent cascade of the shoulders
and would not glisten like a wild beast's fur:

would not, from all the borders of itself,
burst like a star: for here there is no place
that does not see you. You must change your life.

There is a particular shock that comes from being truly seen by something that has no eyes. We wander through galleries and mornings with our own vision leading the way, assuming ourselves to be the sole witnesses of our lives. Then we round a corner and meet a ruin that glows. Rilke’s torso is missing its head, its arms, its legs—dismembered by time, defaced by history—and yet it possesses a completeness that intact statues rarely achieve. The absence becomes a kind of presence, more piercing than any intact gaze.

What arrests us is not the damage but the radiance. The stone has become a lamp, a star, a predator’s pelt, all because something inside it refused to extinguish. It is as if the sculpture understood that being broken is not the same as being dimmed. When Rilke tells us that "there is no place / that does not see you," he is describing an intimacy without comfort. This is not the gentle encouragement of a friend; it is the verdict of beauty that knows our potential. We stand before the fragment and realize we are fragments too—yet here is a fragment that has learned to shine.

The command that ends the poem arrives like a bell after a long silence. It is not a punishment for our failures but the necessary consequence of being recognized. To be seen so utterly is to be reminded that we are still becoming. The torso has surrendered everything but its essence, and in that stripping away, it has grown luminous. Perhaps the change demanded of us is similar: not an accumulation of more, but a fierce, gentle stripping down until we, too, are unable to hide.

The summer river:
although there is a bridge,
my horse goes through the water.

There is a bridge. It stands there, perfectly good, built for exactly this purpose—to carry us across without wetting our feet, without slowing our pace, without the mess of the world touching us. And yet the horse walks into the water. Not because the bridge has failed, not because the horse is stubborn or romantic, but because sometimes the body knows what the map forgets. We spend so much of our lives building bridges—routines, efficiencies, careful plans that keep us above the current, dry and dignified. We forget that the river is not merely an obstacle to be overcome but a place to be inhabited, if only for a moment.

I love that the poem does not tell us whether the rider protests or relents. The horse decides. There is a surrender in that, a recognition that we are not always the ones who must choose the wisest path. We ride atop instincts older than our strategies, and sometimes wisdom means letting the muscles and the hooves feel the cool shock of the stream, the stones shifting beneath, the water rising to the belly. The bridge will still be there when we need it. But today, the horse chooses the way through rather than over.

There is no drama in this decision, no rebellion against civilization. The bridge is not mocked; it simply goes unused this time. It is a quiet declaration that efficiency is not the only virtue, that the direct encounter with what is real—cold, wet, immediate—has its own dignity. We can spend our lives crossing above the current, or we can let the water carry our weight for a while, feeling the pull of the river as it moves, as we move, through the summer afternoon.

No worst, there is none. Pitched past pitch of grief,
More pangs will, schooled at forepangs, wilder wring.
Comforter, where, where is your comforting?
Mary, mother of us, where is your relief?
My cries heave, herds-long; huddle in a main, a chief
Woe, world-sorrow; on an age-old anvil wince and sing—
Then lull, then leave off. Fury had shrieked 'No ling-
ering! Let me be fell: force I must be brief'.

O the mind, mind has mountains; cliffs of fall
Frightful, sheer, no-man-fathomed. Hold them cheap
May who ne'er hung there. Nor does long our small
Durance deal with that steep or deep. Here! creep,
Wretch, under a comfort serves in a whirlwind: all
Life death does end and each day dies with sleep.

There are thresholds of sorrow that feel like the end of language itself, where pain seems to compound beyond its own limits. Hopkins writes from such a place—not to offer a map out, but to testify that these interior landscapes exist, sheer and uncharted. When he speaks of being "pitched past pitch of grief," he captures that vertigo of discovering our capacity for hurting can expand just when we believe we've reached its boundary. The mind reveals itself as terrain more rugged than we imagined, with "cliffs of fall / Frightful, sheer, no-man-fathomed."

It is a lonely geography. The cry for the Comforter goes unanswered; even the maternal solace of Mary offers no relief here. In this solitude, grief becomes a kind of weather we inhabit rather than a storm we watch from safety. Hopkins's sprung, straining rhythms—those enjambments that break across lines like waves—mimic the staggering exhaustion of simply remaining upright in such conditions. We do not choose these descents; they choose us, and we find ourselves "wretch[ed]," huddled beneath whatever shelter we can improvise.

Yet the poem does not end where the anguish peaks. There is a strange, bruised mercy in the final lines—not a triumph, but a recognition of our small endurance. We are given, each evening, a miniature dissolution: "each day dies with sleep." It is not healing, exactly, but it is a reprieve, a rhythm older than our pain. In the willingness to let the day end, to surrender consciousness and trust the dark, we practice the patience that survival requires. The mountains remain, but so does the valley of rest; we climb, descend, and somehow continue.

Death therefore is nothing to us,
nor does it concern us a bit,
since the nature of the mind is proved to be mortal;
and just as in time past we felt no distress,
when round us everywhere
the Carthaginians were rushing to the shock
of war, and all things, shuddering, were filled
with tumult of the shaken firmament,
when humankind, all anxious, hung in doubt
to which, to which dominion all must fall
by land and sea; so, when we are no more,
when comes that sundering of body and soul
whereof the nature and the cause is one,
nothing to us can happen, we not be,
not even were earth confounded with the sea,
and sea with sky.

Some mornings the news feels like the Carthaginians at the gates. Lucretius, writing in the first century BCE, evokes a Rome gripped by the terror of invasion, when "all things, shuddering, were filled / With tumult of the shaken firmament" and no one knew whose dominion would remain when the dust settled. We know this vertigo. It arrives in different uniforms—climate reports, midnight anxieties, the slow unraveling of certainties we mistook for bedrock—but the physiological response is the same: the tightened chest, the scanning of horizons.

What Lucretius offers is not reassurance that the walls will hold, but a stranger comfort. He asks us to remember that we have already survived the worst possible catastrophe. Before the particular constellation of atoms that is each of us came together, there was a silence identical to the one that follows death. We did not suffer then. We were not deprived of anything, because there was no "we" to be deprived. The universe got along perfectly well, rearranging itself into seas and stars and eventually into the temporary pattern reading these words.

This is not nihilism; it is a radical intimacy with existence. To know that non-being is not a punishment but simply the other side of the coin—and one we have already flipped—frees us to occupy this side with less clutching. The atoms that trembled during the Punic Wars are the same ones composing the coffee cup and the hands around it. We are, Lucretius suggests, a brief gathering of that which has always been, returning soon to the dance. The Carthaginians are not coming. They were never the point. The point is that we are here now, while the firmament holds.

Love bade me welcome: yet my soul drew back,
Guilty of dust and sin.
But quick-eyed Love, observing me grow slack
From my first entrance in,
Drew nearer to me, sweetly questioning,
If I lacked anything.

A guest, I answered, worthy to be here:
Love said, You shall be he.
I the unkind, ungrateful? Ah my dear,
I cannot look on thee.
Love took my hand, and smiling did reply,
Who made the eyes but I?

Truth Lord, but I have marred them: let my shame
Go where it doth deserve.
And know you not, says Love, who bore the blame?
My dear, then I will serve.
You must sit down, says Love, and taste my meat:
So I did sit and eat.

There is a peculiar shame that comes with being human, a dustiness that clings to the sleeves of our best intentions. We arrive at the door of our own lives carrying the empty plates of our failures, convinced we must earn the right to sit at the table. We rehearse apologies before we receive invitations, certain that we should be turned away for the stains we carry.

George Herbert’s portrait of Love offers something else entirely—not a ladder to climb, nor a test to pass, but a meal already prepared. The voice in the poem does not argue with our self-accusation; it simply offers a different fact. *Who made the eyes but I?* The question disarms us. We are not being asked to prove our value but to recognize our origin. The shame we carried in the door is not denied or scolded, only gently relieved of its burden and sent where it deserves to go.

To taste the meat is to agree that we are allowed here, in this moment, without having fixed ourselves first. It is the hardest thing—to sit down while still feeling unkind, ungrateful, unfinished. But love, Herbert suggests, is not a reward for cleanliness; it is the very food that makes us capable of being clean. The only requirement is appetite. We eat, and in eating, we become the guest we never believed we could be.
